Award.AwardTitle: Research Collaboration Conference in Number Theory
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support travel to a workshop that will take place from November 16 to 20, 2020 at the Banff International Research Station. It is the fifth in a series of research collaboration conferences. Much of the time during the workshop is reserved for collaboration in small groups led by senior researchers in the field. The major goals of this workshop are to produce significant and impactful research in number theory; help train graduate students and postdocs by providing exposure to new topics and experience with collaborative research and the publication process; strengthen and extend a collaborative research network in number theory and related areas; and enable faculty at smaller colleges to actively participate in research collaborations. More information is available at http://www.birs.ca/events/2020/5-day-workshops/20w5175 and http://www-personal.umich.edu/~weiho/win5/. <br/>The award, which provides travel funding for underrepresented minorities in the mathematical sciences to participate in the workshop at the Banff International Research Stations will also strengthen accessibility by faculty from smaller institutions and at earlier career stage.<br/><br/>This workshop will support the continued development of the number theory community by bringing together researchers at various stages of their careers (including graduate students, postdoctoral researches, tenure-track faculty, and senior mathematicians) for research collaboration and mentoring. The scientific focus of the workshop is on cutting-edge topics in number theory, including dynamical Mahler measure, mock theta functions and related combinatorics, number theory in function fields, q-Analogues of generalized van Hamme supercongruences, representations of p-adic groups, self-dual normal bases and cohomological invariants, supersingular isogeny graphs in cryptography, and zeta functions with coefficients in the Grothendieck-Witt ring.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because of the pandemic, we actually ran two separate events. The first one took place entirely online throughout 2020 and 2021, and the second one took place earlier this year at BIRS, Canada. 
We had 39 participants working in 8 distinct groups in the first conference. The research projects span the spectrum of number theory, from arithmetic statistics to arithmetic geometry, and from cryptography to the p-adic Langlands program. A proceedings volume from the online conference is in the page setting stage with Springer and will appear early next year. It will feature 10 articles, most of which  came out of the research done by the project groups at the conference. It also contains a few contributions from the larger number theory community. 
Throughout 2020 and 2021 we also organized networking and mentoring events for the 39 participants. The groups also gave a series of online presentations about their progress on the projects, which helped both build community, and gave the other participants glimpses into a new field of research, as well as engendered feedback for the group themselves. This was especially appreciated by the junior participants.
The second conference featured 45 participants (39 in person, 6 online) working in 11 distinct groups, and the research projects include a large swath of number theory, including arithmetic dynamics, lattices, quadratic forms, moduli spaces, as well as machine learning. The groups started meeting online before the week in Banff. At BIRS, we had talks from the group leaders introducing each project, as well as informal professional events in the evening (e.g. about job and grant applications). The week ended with presentations by the junior members on the progress of each group up to that point. A proceedings volume for the second conference is in the early stage of planning.
